newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigerian police hunt Shi'ite Moslem leaders.
newsitem.headline: Nigerian police hunt Shi'ite Moslem leaders.

text.p: Nigerian police said on Monday they were searching for Shi'ite Moslem leaders in connection with riots last week in the northern city of Kaduna in which seven people died.
"For now we are still hunting the local leaders," Police Commissioner Yakubu Shaibu told Reuters by telephone from Kaduna.

Two police and five Shi'ites were killed when supporters of the fundamentalist Shi'ite Moslem Brotherhood group demanding the release of their arrested leader, Sheikh Ibrahim Yakub El-Zak-Zaky, fought police last Wednesday.
On Friday, 35 people were brought before a Kaduna magistrate court charged with incitement, public disturbance, unlawful assembly and murder of two police officers.
Shaibu said there had been no more arrests since Thursday.
"The arrests are still going on, we expected them because we are challenging the system," Mohammed Ciroma, a spokesman for the Moslem Brothers said by telephone from Zaria, near Kaduna.
Police say El-Zak-Zaky, a radical preacher, was arrested because of illegal publications and radio broadcasts. He was also alleged to have imported arms.
The Shi'ite group says 14 people were killed in clashes with police a day after El-Zak-Zaky's arrest.
The group is campaigning for imposition of Islamic Sharia law in Africa's most populous nation, although only about half the 100 million people are Moslems, predominantly Sunni.
"We are just trying to continue with our programme as usual, teaching Islamic philosophy and working to deliver Nigeria from this corrupt system of government," Ciroma said.
The mainly Moslem north has been the scene of bloody religious riots in the past.
Last month three people were killed in a clash between rival Moslem sects in Kano, the region's biggest city.
"Everything is calm now and we do not expect any more trouble," said Shaibu.
